The village of Stenness is situated on the main A965 between Kirkwall and Stromess, but is best known for it's
) pass through the village and next to some of the sights along the A965 between
. During the summer, special tourist buses pause for 5 minutes at the Stones of Stenness and 15 minutes at the Ring of Brodgar before continuing on the
The main sights at Stenness are on or within 1km of the A965. You can walk between them, although it's more pleasant to drive as there is no footpath beside the main road.

content=Beside the A965. This chambered tomb is over 5000 years old and considered the finest in North-Western Europe. Facing the winter solstic, the entrance passageway leads to a near perfect interior complete with
left behind by 12th century Viking crusaders.  It is advisable to book ahead at busy times.

About 400m off the A965. Four stones remain from a 12 strong stone circle, dating from about 2500BC. Another stone is atmosperically set beside the bridge between the Loch of Harray and Loch of Stenness.
- the remains of a neolithic village reached by a footpath from the Stones of Stenness. Beware of the midges!
About 1000m from the A965 on the B9055. Stunningly set between two lochs, 27 out of 60 standing stones remain in a circle surround by a ditch and smaller groups of stones and mounds.
There is an ice cream parlour in the village.
